conditions.name: Cardiac Failure
conditions.tips: State the aetiology in the title if known.
resources: RYLC Week 8:  Heart Failure Clarified with Dr Ingrid Hopper

items.text: Change in exercise tolerance since diagnosis (NYHA grading)
Frequency of episodes of decompensation and suspected trigger (infection, arrhythmia, ischaemia, non-adherence)
Number of hospital admissions (ward vs ICU)
Diuretics – hypotension, dyselectrolytaemia, renal impairment, gout
SGLT2 inhibitors – genitourinary infections, euglycaemic ketoacidosis
Frequency of decompensation and suspected trigger (infection, arrhythmia, ischaemia, non-adherence)

conditions.name: Elevated Cardiovascular Risk
conditions.tips: This is a neat way to package a number of related medical problems in a meaninful way.

items.text: Family history of premature CVD (first-degree relative with event <55y male, <65y female)
Elevated BMI and increased waist circumference
Specify type (if known): AF (paroxysmal, persistent, permanent; valvular vs non-valvular), atrial flutter, SVT, VT, VF
Context of diagnosis (eg rAF in acute illness; AF in context of CVA)
Frequency of episodes (eg paroxysmal AF, SVT)
AV node ablation with permanent pacing
Beta-blockers – hypotension, bradycardia, fatigue, bronchospasm, masking of hypoglycaemia
Calcium channel blockers – hypotension, peripheral oedema
Amiodarone – thyroid toxicity, interstitial pneumonitis and fibrosis, hepatotoxicity

conditions.name: Bradyarrhythmias
headingModifiers: Sinus node dysfunction – sinus bradycardia; sinus pause; sinus arrest; sick sinus syndrome (tachy–brady)
AV conduction disease – first-degree AV block; second-degree AV block (Mobitz I; Mobitz II); third-degree AV block
Medication-related bradycardia – β-blockers; non-DHP calcium channel blockers; digoxin; anti-arrhythmics

items.text: Context of diagnosis (eg in the context of acute illness)
Medications and polypharmacy (eg beta blockers, calcium channel blockers)
Dose reduction or cessation of rate-limiting medication
Family history of autoimmunity or diabetes
Previous treatment and reasons for change
Metformin – gastrointestinal upset, B12 deficiency, lactic acidosis
SGLT2 inhibitors – genitourinary infections, euglycaemic ketoacidosis, volume depletion
GLP1 receptor agonists – gastrointestinal side effects, pancreatitis
Hypoglycaemia action plan and sick day management plan
Frequency of BSL checks (finger prick vs CGM)
Sexual dysfunction and impact on relationships

conditions.name: Osteoporosis
resources: RYLC Week 7: Osteoporosis for the Long Case

items.text: Circumstances of diagnosis – routine DEXA vs minimal trauma fracture
Physiotherapy, OT, falls and balance classes
Dental review prior to antiresorptive therapy
Bisphosphonates – oesophagitis, GORD, dysphagia, dyspepsia, hypocalcaemia, osteonecrosis of the jaw, atypical femoral fractures
Denosumab – hypocalcaemia, cellulitis, UTIs, osteonecrosis of the jaw, atypical femoral fractures, rebound vertebral fractures
Raloxifene – VTE, hot flushes, leg cramps
Teriparatide – hypercalcaemia, dizziness, nausea, leg cramps
Romosozumab – arthralgias, headaches, hypocalcaemia, cardiovascular risk
Vertebral fractures – kyphosis, chronic pain, radicular pain

conditions.name: Metabolic Syndrome
conditions.tips: This is a neat way to package a number of related medical problems in a meaninful way.

items.text: Mrs X has metabolic syndrome as evidenced by
Hypertension: on antihypertensive therapy or SBP ≥130 mmHg or DBP ≥85 mmHg
Hyperlipidaemia: on treatment or HDL <1.0 mmol/L (men), <1.3 mmol/L (women), or triglycerides >1.7 mmol/L
Increased abdominal circumference: ≥102 cm (men) or ≥88 cm (women)
Diabetes: on treatment or fasting glucose >5.6 mmol/L
Other risk factors for their elevated cardiovascular risk are:
Family history of premature cardiovascular disease (First-degree male relative <55 years or female relative <65 years
GLP-1 agonists – gastrointestinal side effects, thyroid cancers
Orlistat – gastrointestinal side effects, malabsorption of vitamins A, D, E, K
Physical activity ≥150 minutes per week of moderate-intensity exercise
Regular monitoring of blood pressure, lipids, glucose, and weight

conditions.name: Obesity
resources: RYLC Week  8: Obesity Management & Peri-Operative Risks

items.text: Medications (eg steroids, atypical antipsychotics, insulin, mirtazapine, valproate, lithium)
Age of onset (childhood vs adulthood vs sentinel event)
GLP-1 – gastrointestinal side effects, thyroid cancers
Orlistat – gastrointestinal side effects, malabsorption of vitamins A, D, E, K
Hypertension, dyslipidaemia, ischaemic heart disease, atrial fibrillation
Obstructive sleep apnoea, obesity hypoventilation syndrome
Follow up – by whom and when
Follow up – by whom and when
Hypercalcaemia, renal impairment or bone pain
Cytogenetics or molecular markers (eg bCR-ACL, FLT3 if known)

icons.tip: Package EBV, HTLV-1, hepatitis C here
Package anaemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia

items.text: Follow up: by whom and frequency

conditions.name: Haematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant / Bone Marrow Transplant
conditions.tips: Only Allogeneic HSCT  convey risk of Graft vs Host Disease

items.text: Primary disease or indication for HSCT
Brief vignette of presentation at diagnosis
Brief vignette of disease course prior to transplant
CMV donor and recipient IgG status
Stem cell source (peripheral blood, bone marrow, cord blood)

icons.tip: SYNTHESIS: In an allogeneic HSCT after 100 days immunosuppression and antimicrobials should be ceased unless there are concerns for GVHD.
Link vaccination status here
In an allogeneic HSCT chimerism helps monitor engraftment & risk of disease recurrence

items.text: Follow up – by whom and when

conditions.name: Sickle Cell Disease
conditions.tips: This is a haemoglobinopathy causing chronic haemolysis and recurrent vaso-occlusion, leading to pain crises, infection risk from functional asplenia, and progressive, multi-system end-organ damage.

items.text: Neonatal diagnosis on heel prick testing

icons.tip: Sickle Cell Disease is an autosomal recessive haemoglobinopathy
Increases HbF which is a more 'flexible' Hb, fewer pain crises
Chronic splenic micro-infracts and ischaemia causes functional asplenia
To dilute sickle cells
Preferred if recurrent events. Avoids iron overload.

items.text: Allogeneic bone marrow transplant (curative, select patients)

icons.tip: If your patient has had HSCT, this should be the heading
Link to iron chelation therapy (eg deferasirox)

items.text: Acute pain crises and chronic pain

icons.tip: Link to pain medications
Link to anticoagulation
Papillary necrosis, proteinuria
Severe drop in Hb and reticulocyte count, Parvovirus B19 is a common trigger

items.text: Recurrent infections due to functional asplenia
Impact on work, school, relationships and lifestyle
Link function and symptoms to impact

icons.tip: High risk of complications in pregnancy

Screening partner is recommended. Options for genetic counselling to be aware of are pre-implantation diagnosis, chorionic villous sampling (11-13 weeks gestation), amniocentesis (>15 weeks gestation)

items.text: Follow up – by whom and when

conditions.name: Thalassaemia
conditions.tips: If the patient has a mild anaemia and minor carrier state thalassaemia only list this as a brief less active problem

items.text: Neonatal screening on heel prick testing

icons.tip: This is an autosomal recessive haemoglobinopathy - two abnormal genes (one from each parent) are needed cause disease

items.text: Common in African, Asian, Middle Eastern descent
Regular red cell transfusions and frequency (often 3-4 weekly)

icons.tip: The goal is to supress erythropoiesis to reduce bony expansion and defomity
Iron overload is inevitable due to transfusions. Note patient might be on oral iron chelation or subcutaneous drivers.

items.text: HBV, HCV, HIV risk in older patients (due to blood products)

icons.tip: Osteoporosis in thalassaemia is multifactorial - related to marrow expansion, iron overload and hypogonadism

items.text: Pre-transfusion Hb greater than 110 g/L if cardiac disease
Ferritin approximately 700 µg/L (or less than 1000 µg/L)
Cardiac and liver MRI every 12–18 months
Impact on work, school, relationships, lifestyle
Travel limitations due to transfusion schedule

icons.tip: High risk complications in pregnancy

Screening partner is recommended. Options for genetic counselling to be aware of are pre-implantation diagnosis, chorionic villous sampling (11-13 weeks gestation), amniocentesis (>15 weeks gestation)

items.text: Follow up – by whom and when

conditions.name: Haemophilia
conditions.tips:
Severity, Factor Level & Presentation - 
Severe: <1% (spontaneous joint/muscle bleeds)
Moderate: 1–5% (bleeds after minor trauma or procedures)
Mild: >5% (bleeds only after major trauma/surgery)

items.text: Elevated APTT correcting with mixing study
Identified hospital for acute presentation (consider rural patients)
Factor replacement therapy (on demand vs prophylactic)
Self-administered or carer-administered (especially if functional impairments)
Bypassing agent (recombinant Factor VIIa) for inhibitor development

icons.tip: A bispecific antibody binds factor 9 and 10 (ie. mimics the function of factor 8) which can be used with or without inhibitors to factor 8

items.text: Blood-borne viruses (HIV, Hepatitis C) in older patients

icons.tip: This group are an ageing population who are now experiencing traditional CV risk, anticoagulation decisions become more complex!

items.text: Aim factor levels > 50 % for minor surgery
For males - daughters would be carriers
For female carriers - 50% chance of affected son & 50% chance carrier daughter
Options for prenatal or postnatal diagnosis for natural conception
Follow up – by whom and when

conditions.name: Human Immunodeficiency Virus
resources: RYLC Week 6: HIV Long Case with Dr Rehka Pai Mangalore

items.text: Seroconversion illness at lower viral loads
CD4 count / viral load at diagnosis
Infections including opportunistic infections and AIDS-defining illnesses and management

sectionIcons.tip:
Terminology which could be used here is:
- low-level viraemia
- virological  suppression
- incomplete virological response
- virological suppression
- virological treatment failure
- virological rebound

items.text: Smoking cessation and cardiovascular risk reduction

icons.tip: Backbone of most regimens

items.text: Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate, Tenofovir alafenamide, Emtricitabine, Lamivudine, Abacavir, Zidovudine

icons.tip: First-line in most modern regimens
Always boosted
Not active ART themselves
Selected or resistant cases

items.text: TMP-SMX for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia if CD4 <200
TMP-SMX for Toxoplasma gondii if CD4 <100
Azithromycin or clarithromycin for Mycobacterium avium complex if CD4 <50
Gastrointestinal upset, fatigue, headache, dizziness, sleep disturbance, rash, pruritus, myalgias, arthralgias, transaminitis, drug–drug interactions
Lipodystrophy, weight gain, dyslipidaemia, insulin resistance

icons.tip: Package minor IHD here.
Package osteoporosis and DEXA scans here.

items.text: Follow up – by whom and when

conditions.name: End Stage Renal Failure On Dialysis

items.text: Haemodialysis: Attendance __ times weekly for ___ hours

icons.tip: Peritoneal Dialysis may not be fluid restricted if good urine output

Ask how much fluid is removed on dialysis?,
Or use weight as a guide: (Weight at start HDx) - (Weight at end HDx) should = 1kg = 1L, IDG represents adherence to fluid restriction: 1-2L is acceptable, 3-4L suggests poor adherence.

items.text: Follow up – by whom and when

conditions.name: End Stage Renal Failure
conditions.tips:
CKD Stage 1: eGFR ≥90 mL/min/1.73 m²,
CKD Stage 2: eGFR 60–89 mL/min/1.73 m²,
CKD Stage 3a: eGFR 45–59 mL/min/1.73 m²,
CKD Stage 3b: eGFR 30–44 mL/min/1.73 m²,
CKD Stage 4: eGFR 15–29 mL/min/1.73 m²,
CKD Stage 5: eGFR <15 mL/min/1.73 m²,

items.text: Renal replacement therapy planning if progressive

conditions.name: General Neurology
conditions.tips: Of course, title with the patient’s diagnosed neurological condition! But this card details what is most important to elucidate in any neurological long case.
resources: YouTube Video - Neurological History in a Jiffy!

items.text: Investigations at diagnosis (bloods, CTB, MRIB, LP, EEG)
eg. anticoagulation and statin for previous stroke
Management: glasses, eye patch, guide dog
Management: dietician, thickened feeds, NG feeds, PEG feeds
Management: braces, splints, orthoses, OT, physio, exercises, home modifications
Bowel and bladder deficits (urinary retention or incontinence, constipation, faecal incontinence)
Management: urinary catheter, bowel or bladder regimen
Global impact of illness – pre-diagnosis function vs current function
Follow up: by whom and frequency
Glucocorticoids (PO, IV) – quantity, frequency, dose for steroid burden
Interferon beta – fever, myalgia, headache, fatigue, injection-site reactions, mood disturbance, hepatotoxicity, bone marrow suppression, thyroid dysfunction
Glatiramer acetate – injection-site reactions, immediate post-injection reaction (chest tightness, flushing, dyspnoea, palpitations)

Fingolimod – headache, fatigue, bradycardia and AV block (first dose), macular oedema, lymphopenia, infection risk (especially herpes viruses), rebound disease activity on cessation, hypertension, hepatotoxicity
Dimethyl fumarate – flushing, gastrointestinal upset, lymphopenia, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, hepatotoxicity
Teriflunomide – gastrointestinal upset, alopecia, teratogenicity (requires prolonged washout), hepatotoxicity, peripheral neuropathy, hypertension, bone marrow suppression
Natalizumab – headache, fatigue, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (JC virus–positive), serious infections, hypersensitivity reactions, rebound disease activity on withdrawal
Ocrelizumab – infusion-related reactions, upper respiratory tract infections, serious infections, hypogammaglobulinaemia, possible increased malignancy risk
Alemtuzumab – infusion reactions, infections, secondary autoimmune disease (thyroid disease, immune-mediated thrombocytopenia, anti–GBM disease), increased malignancy risk
Management: glasses, eye patch, guide dog
Management: dietician, thickened feeds, NG feeds, PEG feeds
Management: braces, splints, orthoses, OT, physio, exercises, home modifications
Bowel and bladder deficits (urinary retention or incontinence, constipation, faecal incontinence)
Management: urinary catheter, bowel or bladder regimen
Global impact of illness – pre-diagnosis function vs current function
Follow up: by whom and frequency

conditions.name: Cerebrovascular Accident
conditions.tips: If the patient has significant, persistent functional impact (eg. Hemiparesis) consider stating this upfront within the heading

items.text: Stability or recovery of neurological deficits
Management: glasses, eye patch, guide dog
Management: dietician, thickened feeds, NG feeds, PEG feeds
Management: braces, splints, orthoses, OT, physio, exercises, home modifications
Bowel and bladder deficits (urinary retention or incontinence, constipation, faecal incontinence)
Management: urinary catheter, bowel or bladder regimen
Global impact of illness – pre-diagnosis function vs current function
Follow up: by whom and frequency

conditions.name: Epilepsy
headingModifiers: Focal Onset (Aware / Impaired Awareness / Motor Onset / Non-Motor Onset)
Epilepsy Syndromes (Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy / Lennox–Gastaut syndrome / Childhood absence epilepsy)

items.text: Prior CNS insult (stroke, CNS infection, tumour)
Sodium valproate – nausea/vomiting, weight gain, tremor, sedation, hepatotoxicity, pancreatitis, thrombocytopenia, hyperammonaemia, alopecia
Levetiracetam / brivaracetam – fatigue/dizziness, behavioural disturbance (irritability, agitation, aggression), mood changes/depression
Lamotrigine – dizziness/headache, nausea, rash, Stevens–Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis (especially rapid titration), aseptic meningitis
Topiramate – cognitive slowing (word-finding difficulties), paraesthesia, weight loss, renal calculi, metabolic acidosis, angle-closure glaucoma
Carbamazepine / oxcarbazepine – dizziness/diplopia/ataxia/nausea, hyponatraemia, bone marrow suppression, Stevens–Johnson syndrome, hepatotoxicity
Phenytoin – nystagmus/ataxia/diplopia, gingival hyperplasia, peripheral neuropathy, osteopenia/osteoporosis, megaloblastic anaemia, Stevens–Johnson syndrome
Ethosuximide – gastrointestinal upset, fatigue/headache, behavioural changes, bone marrow suppression, Stevens–Johnson syndrome
Benzodiazepines – sedation/drowsiness/dizziness, cognitive impairment, respiratory depression, tolerance and dependence, withdrawal seizures, falls risk
Global impact of illness – pre-diagnosis function vs current function
Follow up: by whom and frequency
Molecular markers if known (EGFR, BRAF, HER2, PD-L1)

icons.tip: Package EGFR, ALK, KRAS, BRAF, HER2, PD-L1 here

items.text: Disease trajectory (curative, remission, stable, progressive, relapsed)
Follow up: by whom and frequency

conditions.name: Chronic Obstructve Pulmonary Disease
headingModifiers:
Severity
- Mild FEV₁ ≥ 80% predicted
- Moderate FEV₁ 50–79% predicted
- Severe FEV₁ 30–49% predicted
- Very severe FEV₁ < 30% predicted

Phenotype
- Emphysema-predominant COPD
- Chronic bronchitis phenotype
- Asthma–COPD overlap

items.text: Infective vs non-infective exacerbations at presentation
Occupational or environmental exposure (bushfires, mining, construction)
Change in exercise tolerance since diagnosis (mMRC grading)
Follow up – by whom and when

conditions.name: Interstital Lung Disease
headingModifiers:
Pattern
- Usual interstitial pneumonia pattern
- Nonspecific interstitial pneumonia
- Organising pneumonia
- Hypersensitivity pneumonitis

Cause
- Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis 
- Connective tissue disease–associated ILD
- Drug-induced ILD
- Occupational ILD

items.text: Connective tissue disease (systemic sclerosis, RA, myositis)
Pirfenidone – gastrointestinal upset (nausea, dyspepsia), photosensitivity rash, fatigue, hepatotoxicity
Nintedanib – diarrhoea, nausea/vomiting, hepatotoxicity, bleeding risk
Glucocorticoids – weight gain, osteoporosis, hyperglycaemia, infection risk, mood change
Mycophenolate mofetil – gastrointestinal upset, cytopenias, infection risk
Azathioprine – bone marrow suppression, hepatotoxicity, pancreatitis, infection risk
Cyclophosphamide – myelosuppression, haemorrhagic cystitis, infertility, malignancy risk, infection risk
Rituximab – infusion reactions, hypogammaglobulinaemia, infection risk, hepatitis B reactivation
Tocilizumab – infection risk, transaminitis, neutropenia, hyperlipidaemia, GI perforation (rare)
Follow up – by whom and when
Often diagnosed at birth via newborn screening
Diagnosed in infancy (meconium ileus, failure to thrive)
Later presentation with recurrent respiratory infections, malabsorption, or infertility
Genetic mutation if known (ΔF508 most common)
Frequency of lower respiratory tract infections
High-energy diet with fat-soluble vitamin supplementation
Airway clearance and physiotherapy – fatigue, musculoskeletal strain
Dornase alfa – voice alteration, pharyngitis, rash
Long-term azithromycin – QT prolongation, hearing disturbance, gastrointestinal upset
CFTR modulators – transaminitis, rash, cataracts (paediatric), drug–drug interactions
Follow up – by whom and when

conditions.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
resources: RYLC Week 7: Live Practise Session "Multifactorial Pain Syndromes"

items.text: Synovitis / erosions on XR / US / MRI

icons.tip: Package less active autoimmune medical problems which don't require a detailed, separate presentation (eg. autoimmune neutropaenia, Sjogren's disease, Hashimoto's thyroiditis)

items.text: Disease severity and trajectory (progressive, relapsing–remitting, or well controlled)
Past treatment, why this was ceased or changed
Overall steroid burden (frequency / duration of steroids, highest dose / lowest dose patient has been on)
Physiotherapy / OT / Hand Therapy / Exercise Physiology
Foot orthoses / Hand splints / Gait aids
TNF inhibitors (adalimumab, certolizumab pegol, etanercept, golimumab, infliximab)

pADLs: consider self-injecting medication, opening medication bottles

Disease severity and trajectory (progressive, relapsing–remitting, or well controlled)
Frequency of flares and NSAID requirement

conditions.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
conditions.tips:
Consider listing the main manifestations upfront.
If the patient has lupus nephritis then use this as this  heading and discuss as you would a renal problem - touching on the less serious manifestations within complications or symptoms.
resources: RYLC Week 7: Lupus, Scleroderma & More with Professor Michelle Leech

items.text: ANA, ENA, dsDNA, C3, C4, ESR, CRP, Anti-phospholipid antibodies
Drugs (TNF inhibitors, hydralazine, isoniazid, procainamide, minocycline)
Disease severity and trajectory (progressive, relapsing–remitting, or well controlled)
Past treatment and reasons for escalation or cessation
Overall steroid burden (frequency and duration, highest and lowest dose)

icons.tip: Package immunisation status here

items.text: Metabolic complications (especially if high steroid burden)

Package occular screening here

icons.tip: Package IHD here if relevant (but if signiifcant detail and needs to be presented separately, also do so)

conditions.name: Systemic Sclerosis
headingModifiers: Overlap Syndrome (eg with SLE or myositis)
resources: RYLC Week 7: Lupus, Scleroderma & More with Professor Michelle Leech

items.text: ANA, ENA, RNA polymerase III, CK, ESR, CRP
Malignancy (if temporally related to systemic sclerosis onset)
Disease severity and trajectory (progressive, relapsing–remitting, or well controlled)
Past treatment and reasons for escalation or cessation
Overall steroid burden (frequency and duration, highest and lowest dose)

icons.tip: Package immunisation status here

items.text: Metabolic complications (especially if high steroid burden)

icons.tip: Package cancer screening here
Package ocular screening here

items.text: Methotrexate – cytopaenias, hepatitis, pneumonitis, interstitial lung disease, gastrointestinal upset
Pulmonary arterial hypertension (limited cutaneous) or interstitial lung disease (diffuse cutaneous)
Scleroderma renal disease or renal crisis
pADLs: consider self-injecting medication, opening medication bottles
Assess organ involvement and disease activity
Follow up: by whom and frequency
Cause of ESKD and when diagnosed
Symptoms and investigations at diagnosis of ESKD

icons.tip: Keep this brief - just make sure you know why they needed a transplant and agree with the diagnosis. Avoid a long drawn out chronological history of time of CKD diagnosis to transplant.

items.text: Risk factors for sensitisation (pregnancy, transfusion, prior transplant)
Infections (BK, CMV, PJP, UTI, others major infection)

icons.tip: Package malignancy screening including skin checks

items.text: Cytopenias ((e.g MMF, AZA, mTORi, Valcyte, Bactrim, CMV, parvovirus)

icons.tip: Most patients with a solid organ transplant patients are taking three immunosuppressants (liver transplant in the longer term are on two agents). Sometimes patients are on two agents by design - but if they are on less than three agents you should check if their immunosuppression was reduced for a particular reason (eg infection or malignancy).
Package vaccination status here

If a transplant patient is receiving an antimicrobial make sure you know why.  Is it routine prophylaxis? Or have they had an infection? Or an increase in their immunosuppression for rejection necessitating re-introduction of antimirobials?

items.text: Population cancer screening up to date

icons.tip: If patient has pre-existing diabetes with complications before transplant – discuss separately but nod toward it here, If patient has developed diabetes post-transplant and the transplant was recent (insufficient time to develop complications of diabetes) diabetes can be handled here briefly.
Package DEXA screening and OP medications here.
Package PPIs here.
A renal transplant is a single kidney, patients have various ranges of function. General CKD complications may to the transplant patient if GFR is low - look for clues on med chart.
Patients should know their baseline eGFR and creatnine!

sectionIcons.tip: This is very important in a transplant patient!

items.text: Symptoms of graft dysfunction if present
Immunosuppressant drug levels within transplant team target
Plans if graft failing (dialysis or re-transplant)

conditions.name: Falls
headingModifiers: On a background of untreated osteoporsis
conditions.tips: This is a neat way to package a number of related medical problems in a meaninful way.

items.text: Number of falls or 'near misses' over defined time period
The predominant pattern / nature of the falls has been
Brief vignette of most recent fall

icons.tip: Package or link osteoporosis, osteopaenia here.
Package or link anticoagulation here.

conditions.name: Multifactorial Pain
conditions.tips: This is a neat way to package medical problems which could cause pain when there is not one, single obvious cause of the pain syndrome.

items.text: Mr X has a multifactorial pain syndrome, related to his known / suspected
Spinal disease and nerve root compression
Myalgia, arthralgia, axial, peripheral, widespread or radicular
Follow up – by whom and when
Circumstances at onset (Sentinel event, bereavement, illness, divorce, burnout)
Psychology such as CBT or ACT

icons.tip: often used if there is pain as a comorbidity

items.text: Mirtazapine if insomnia or weight loss

icons.tip: often used if concurrent insomnia or weight loss

items.text: Loss of appetite or weight loss
Impact on adherence to management of other medical problems
Impact on relationships or on otehrs
Follow up – by whom and when
